title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: The HR reached out to me first. It is a 30 minutes interview. She asked about my previous intern experience and volunteer experience. Then a week later, the future supervisor reached out to me to have another video interview.
Interview Questions: Walk through your resume; describe your volunteer experience.

title: Project Lead Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions: I had an interview with the recruiter manager and hiring manager. During the interview everything was good, I felt comfortable answering common questions about my professional experience. However, I felt really disappointed, I did not have feedback about my process, and they never contacted me again!!, that's very unprofessional. I prepared for many days for my interview and I was excited to get this job, That is really unfair with job-seekers :(
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work with us?

title: Product Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: I had an extremely negative experience interviewing with World Resources Institute. The interview process was lengthy and exhausting, and the recruiter I worked with was incredibly discourteous and disrespectful. After the initial interview, I was left in the dark for nearly a month with no communication from the company. Eventually, the hiring manager reached out to me, only to ghost me for nearly two weeks after that. When she finally did get back to me, she told me that she didn't think I would be a good fit for the role and that I would be frustrated with the job and her ability to manage me effectively. I found this to be incredibly discriminatory and judgmental, especially given that she had initially told me that I was highly qualified. To make matters worse, she then went on to say that there were other applicants who would be able to step into the role more easily and that the company wasn't interested in training anyone. She even went so far as to suggest that my location on the West Coast would make it difficult for me to succeed in the role, despite my qualifications and abilities. Overall, my experience with World Resources Institute was totally unfair and unprofessional. The company clearly has a lot of work to do in terms of its hiring practices and treating candidates with respect and dignity. I would not recommend applying for a job with this company based on my negative experience.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself and your background.

title: Development Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 months. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: Process was super long and HR staff is inexperieced and unprofessional. Process took more than 3 months. After moving thru 4 rounds of interviews, they went ghost and I never heard back from them. Stay away from this organization. While they have a great mission, they clearly don't value candidates or employees considering their low pay and unprofessional hiring practices. This is the type of organization you only work for if you are  desperate and have no other options. No wonder why their turnover is so high.
Interview Questions: tell me about a time you had to go above and beyond for a client

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: A short phone screening. Asked questions that you would usually get at interviews: introduce yourself, why do you think you would be a good fit for the job, etc. Even if you applied for multiple position at the same time, you are screened only once.
Interview Questions: Why do you think you are a good fit?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: It was fun. The HR team especially was very nice and describe the job really well. The research team's questions were very specific. However, the process is quite long and they haven't called me back despite my request for personal feedback. It would be nice if they can provide it.
Interview Questions: How do you develop research question?

title: Communications Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: The process was pretty fast and seamless but there were multiple rounds which took some time. Everyone was respectful of my time and I felt gave me sufficient time to ask my own questions.
Interview Questions: Describe your experience with social media strategy

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Very fast and responsive. I had 3 rounds of interviews. One with the reporting manager, one with the team and then the HR round. The interview process was a conversation more than an interview to try and understand past experience and interest in the sector
Interview Questions: Questions related to past experience and interest in the sector

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: first stage conversation with hiring focal point, simple conversation to get to know each other expectations for the role and the strategic goals they have sought out. Did not get a sense of what future conversations or process would like.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply for this role

title: Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: Panelists were extremely friendly and seemed to enjoy working at WRI. Seems like a collaborative, mission-driven environment. Questions were very resume-based and the process was well-streamlined. Phone screen --> video panel interview --> writing sample --> offer.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you encountered a problem during your research and how you overcame it.

title: Sustainable Mobility Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Oct 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview lasted for around 40 minutes, and there were 3 interviewers: HR, the project lead, and a mobility consultant. The interview session started with the HR explaining about the project brief, including the timeline of the whole project, and what to expect of the role on each phase of the project.
Interview Questions: - Understanding about sustainable mobility - Knowledge about current issue on the specific city of the project - Skills in GHG emissions and transportation/ mobility software

title: Communications Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Phone screen with supervisor followed by in person discussion. Writing exercise required. Fair and transparent process with reasonable people. Ultimately the role wasn't for me but wouldn't discourage someone from applying!
Interview Questions: Why do you want to switch into a comms role (I'd been in a different position at my then-employer).

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: I applied and a few days later was contacted to schedule interview for the job, which was great. After I was contacted to schedule the interview I replied promptly with my availability for the next two weeks, but was not contacted until 3 weeks later to schedule my first interview, which was only a screening interview. I followed up appropriately during that period of not hearing anything back, but sometimes my emails were met with no reply. Nearly one month later I was moved forward to a panel interview with the team, who asked some tough and technical questions but I felt I answered them well. After that interview I promptly was moved forward to a writing sample, which was one hour and asked me to write a blog post about the topic for the job I was applying for. The writing sample was difficult and I did my best, but I definitely could have done better. Either way, what followed was a series of emails with the HR recruiter. I kept getting led on by the recruiter and got a few emails and calls saying I would hear back from him soon, but I never did. The process was dragged out for a few months and I was effectively ghosted by the HR recruiter. I don't think this reflects much on the actual team I would be working for but it definitely did not reflect well on the organization as a whole.
Interview Questions: How do you approach working with a new subject area?

title: Policy Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: early-round interview, conducted by phone with a program lead; it was informational both ways, and brought to light that relocation might be a sticking point for moving forward with the process
Interview Questions: Why would I want to transition from my industry to WRI?

title: Events Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: There are 3 stages in the interview process. The first one is with the HR, the 2nd is with the position-specific 2 people and the third one is with the panel of 5 people (obviously all related to the position/project). It is very smooth, friendly, calm and quick process. HR gets back to you in around a week with the outcome and next steps. Questions were regarding - previous and relevant experience, crisis situations, communication skills, managing multiple stakeholders, position-specific technical skills, what one find exciting and challenging in this job, future prospects. Overall, it was a very pleasant experience.
Interview Questions: Questions were regarding - previous and relevant experience, crisis situations, communication skills, managing multiple stakeholders, position-specific technical skills, what one find exciting and challenging in this job, future prospects. Overall, it was a very pleasant experience.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Received an interview request after a few weeks. Talked with someone over the phone for a bit who seemed unprepared to interview someone. The next steps was a panel interview then a skills test.
Interview Questions: How does your skill relate to this job

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions: The entire process took 4 months, with 4 weeks between the second interview and communication regarding the outcome of that interview. Eventually after 4 months, I was notified that they decided not to fill the role.
Interview Questions: Q. Why did you choose WRI?

title: Project Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: The process was very laid back. I heard back after applying online. I gave two interviews before I got the offer. However, the part time position did not offer benefits.
Interview Questions:
Tell me about yourself. 
How do you see yourself in this role?

title: Learning and Development Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: 15 minute phone screening with HR. 30 minute phone call with hiring manager. 60 minute panel interview with 4 people, some from team some from elsewhere on the organization. 60 minute work sample exercise.
Interview Questions: What excites you about work?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed at WRI twice for an internship position. A couple of general questions at Screening. Followed by a 30 minute interview with the hiring manager about interest in the position. Smooth process although they tend to ghost after the final round of interviews.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Interviewer seemed ill prepared for the interview. Did not seem like their team cared to hire anyone. Instead just asked basic questions and I was surprised to make it to the next round.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you worked on a team

title: Communications & Engagement Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: I applied online, went through a phone screening with HR followed by two interviews and a writing exercise. I didn’t have enough time to really get through the exercise properly but I’d say just do your best.
Interview Questions: How would you manage if abc situation came up with partners/stakeholders?

title: Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Screener call with HR followed by a 1 hour call with hiring manager followed by one hour Zoom panel with Director and two senior managers.

It was rather straight forward. The team was engaged in the conversation, making it feel very comfortable and easy. Clear commitment to the work!
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in WRI and this role?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: First a phone screening with a recruiter, normal questions, then a call with hiring manager, and then a panel interview.  Panel interview is much more technical than the phone screening, and they all asked unique and intentional questions.
Interview Questions: What drew you to this job opportunity

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview process followed several steps as follows: - 30-minute phone call with a human resources representative - Call with manager for the position - Virtual panel interview - Written exercise
Interview Questions: What interested you in this position? Tell us about yourself. Do you have experience curating social media profiles?

title: Finance Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Had three interviews with five different people, one of which was a panel of three staff in the immediate office of employment. Questions were appropriate for the position. Not too serious, we were able to have a few laughs.
Interview Questions: Have you had experience managing up?

title: Program Specialist II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: 15 min phone screen with recruiter and then interview with hiring manager and then a third interview with a panel group. Also included a timed work exercise before checking references
Interview Questions: Describe a time where you had to solve a complex problem

title: Research Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: The first interview was with HR, introductory for the most part.  They asked basic questions- why are you interested in the job etc.  The interview also included some logistical questions such as when you would like to start working if you were hired.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in the job?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: First there was a basic phone screening with an HR employee lasting around 15 minutes. Next I attended an in-person interview with a panel of 4 employees. Finally I did a budgeting exercise.
Interview Questions: There were a lot of "tell me about a time" type questions, so it is helpful to prepare anecdotes in advance.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Friendly, on time, good experience. CV asked expectations asked, synergies explored, discussed other ambitious projects, Salary discussed., benchmarks & renumeration. company culture, climate change in India and in the global south
Interview Questions: What is your salary expectation

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Had my first round interview with a manager on the team and it was a normal, get-to-know-you type of conversation. Overall was pleasant and straightforward and indicated that I'd hear back about the role soon as they were hoping to have a start date within the next month. I followed up 3 times (over the course of 6 weeks) and never heard back about the role. I thought this was incredibly unprofessional and rude!
Interview Questions: Tell me about your background in this field.

title: Analista De Mobilidade Urbana Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul)
Interview Descriptions: Entrevista em grupo, um pouco corrida. Poucas oportunidades de ser avaliado, reconheço que processos individuais demandam muito tempo, porém acho pouco efetivo entrevistas coletivas como foi realizada. No entanto, uma instituição muito interessante para quem deseja evoluir na área da mobilidade e do transporte urbano.
Interview Questions: Se apresentar de forma criativa.

title: Junior Product Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: I had a quick screening with a member of the HR team (who was able to give me details about company culture, etc), an hour-long call with the hiring manager, a third panel interview with people who would eventually be my teammates, and then a writing test.
Interview Questions: What is a situation in which you've had to pay close attention to detail?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: First round is a 20 minute call. Questions included basic get-to-know-you and specific knowledge. Second round is a panel interview with other staff members in the office. Similar to other types of panel interviews.
Interview Questions: Specific knowledge about Articles within the Paris Agreement.

title: Energy Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: Three levels - Two interviews and One Writing test. One was estimating fit, the second was a knowledge and experience test, and the last a writing test clocked at one hour.
Interview Questions: Basic energy-related questions that one would expect if they've done their research

title: Marketing Communications Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: Applied directly on the website. First had a phone screening. Then, a panel interview with key team members. This was followed by a writing test that had to be returned within an hour of receiving it. Questions on the writing test consisted of drafting tweets and proposing graphics, and copyediting a press statement.
Interview Questions: Give an example about working in a team environment.

title: Senior Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Applied & heard back within 2-3 weeks. Recruiter screener call (10-15 mins), 1st round panel (2 similar level interviewers), 2nd round panel (3 director-level interviewers). Style of situational STAR method responses - no case studies, exams, or anything.
Interview Questions:
- What is your leadership style?
- Tell me about a time when X, Y, Z...
- How would you juggle multiple priorities?

title: Sustainable Cities Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Beijing, Beijing) in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: The whole interview atmosphere is very relaxed, no test, basically personal introduction, past experience, past project introduction, personal ability. received the offer during the interview, and an official email acceptance a week later.

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: It was generally smooth. The panel interview was a bit daunting. I wish they’d give more clarity on the exam format. Overall, it was a good interview experience — very smart group of experts, who are obviously very passionate about what they do.
Interview Questions: Writing sample & excel exercice

title: Research Associate - Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Easy and very good communication, positive interactions, helpful staff, interesting position. Had to submit basic materials such as resume, cover letter, and examples of work. I really enjoyed getting to know WRI through the process.
Interview Questions: How is your work ethic

title: Legal Counsel Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Mumbai) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: good. It was taken by HR and CEO. The questions asked were mainly about the past experience and FCRA compliances. Final interview as taken by Legal Counsel, US. The interview process was about 30 days long.
Interview Questions: What was your past experience

title: Clean Energy Advocate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online and received an email to set up initial phone screen with recruiter about 3 weeks later. The initial call was 30 mins, pretty easy questions. I was then asked to have a virtual interview with 2 people on the team. The email from the recruiter was sent around 10am asking for my availability, she then emailed again at 12 to provide my availability ASAP. 

45 min virtual interview with 2 people. No feedback for 2 weeks until I received a generic email thanking me for my time, but that I was no longer a candidate. Process seemed impersonal.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you had to learn a new skill

title: Corporate Communications Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: The interviewe process was smooth. One thirty-minute behavioral interview with both hiring managers followed by a writing assessment. The questions were not overly difficult, but do research beforehand! They were impressed by my knowledge of the company. Heard back shortly and accepted the offer.
Interview Questions: What do you know about WRI?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
Process overall ok but extremely drawn out. Felt like my time was wasted - taken to final interview and then ghosted. Position was meant to start in February ’21, then pushed back to March ’21. I don’t even know what’s going on with it now as I was never notified of anything and emails to hiring managers have been ignored. 

Applied November 2020. Invitation for initial interview with two staff in December 2020. Got asked to do a short writing task in January 2021. A few weeks later asked to do a second interview in February 2021. Interviews themselves were fairly straightforward questions about my background and a few open-ended questions about different things related to strategy and evaluation as this was the focus of the internship. No behavioural questions. Writing task was summarising some program information on a one-pager.
Interview Questions: Tell us a little more about your experience etc?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
Fairly standard process. I interviewed remotely due to COVID. It was a group interview. 

I heard back within 2 weeks or so and was then asked to supply 2-3 references and complete a sample work assignment.
Interview Questions:
Why WRI? 
What relevant experience do you have that would help you succeed at this internship?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Some from the company calls to screen applicants they want to invite for interviews, they will share the benefits that come with the role and compensation, if you accept them, then you're invited for a first interview with your immediate supervisor and after a panel interview
Interview Questions: Describe a time you had a conflict with a colleague and how did you solve it?

title: Consumer & Market Knowledge Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Application procedure involved CV, Cover letter, interview and then assessment round. The assessment round encompassed the submission of a report review which needed to detail specific requirements related to the role of the application.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in the role? What are some of the things which link you to this role? Very basic questions

title: Consultant for Gender Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: There is only 1 session of interview and it's rather straightforward. They asked question specific to the jobs and has diversed range of panels (across multi-national team). After interview, they will follow up with the decision. I like it as they did not drag the recruitment process too long
Interview Questions: What method do you use to conduct gender assessment?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Very very long interview process, took over a month and a half just to receive a rejection. Way too many steps for an entry-level position with no research aspect. Asked the same questions at each interview phase. However, everyone I spoke with was very nice.
Interview Questions: Why would you want to work at WRI? What are three strengths and weaknesses?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview - Horrible experience. The interviewer was just visibly not interested and even sounded bored. It felt like she was just conducting the interview to get it over with.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for WRI?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: A month or two after sending my application, I interviewed over the phone. Then, shortly after, I was invited to complete a timed written exercise. I heard back a week or two later with an offer.
Interview Questions: [cannot recall at this point, but it was very relaxed]

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (São Paulo, São Paulo) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: Fine, friendly and fair. Exposition about overall interest and challenges. Interviewer was well intended and motivated but poorly briefed from intl direction and board. Apointed to hiring but was later on counter feit.
Interview Questions: General, about specific track record and management skills

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (London, ON) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: They take a long to share feedback which often leads to candidates' fatigue. The salary scale also doesn't correspond to the position. More investment needed in the hiring and recruitment
Interview Questions: How do you rate yourself to the role advertised

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Open-minded, welcoming, several practice assignments, overall smooth. Space to ask questions and tell them about your ideas. The interview itself was conducted in a very friendly environment. WRI was quick to respond and the overall process was transparent and pleasant,
Interview Questions:
Why WRI?
Practical skills
Practice assessments
Learning opportunity

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: There were two stages of interviews. Both of them were semi-technical. The interviews went good but the interviewers didn't give any feedback or result. It's been more than two months now and I don't think they will contact me again.
Interview Questions: If I get a PhD offer while I am working for them, will I accept the offer?

title: Epp Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
By Microsoft team about 20 minutes they have taken the interview by 2 persons. They were very calm, positive and supportive throughout the interview.
Then they asked me some questions about my previous jobs. The questions they have asked was very logical.
Interview Questions: Tell me something about yourself was the first question.

title: Intern Interview

Interview Descriptions: I applied for an internship position for a project that has been going on for the past 2 years. The interview was attended by 4 people from the company - 1 of them was the HR, 2 of them are from the project, and 1 being the specialist but was not part of the project. The interview took approximately 90 minutes, all held in English (the job was in Indonesia).
Interview Questions: How do I know the company, my thesis project/research (I applied for his position 3 months after graduation), my technical/engineering skills, my overall basic knowledge of how the project is gonna be.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions: Due to COVID-19, the interview was over Zoom. There were several technical difficulties but the interviewer was very understanding about them. The interview was about 45 minutes. After the initial interview, they asked me to perform a one-hour technical writing test, where I needed to write LinkedIn, Twitter, and Facebook posts.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Oct 2020
Interview Descriptions: 30 minute phone interview with technical recruiter followed by 30 minute general phone interview with hiring manager, followed by a panel interview with hiring managers and a coding assignment to demonstrate skills
Interview Questions: What data analytics tools do you have experience with?

title: Communications Lead Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was done with the HR, project lead, and the user. It is a case study basis which will depend on your experience, network, and skill. 

Additionally, there will be a reference check as well.
Interview Questions:
1. How do you communicate issue such as [project name] to audience such as public, government, or other parties

2. What tools do you use to communicate

3. Give one example of how a successful campaign would be

title: Digital Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Sept 2020
Interview Descriptions: Very frustrating interview process overall. I had an initial enjoyable phone screen interview with a member of the team, and was shortly moved to a panel interview with a couple more members of the core communications team. After the panel interview, I received  a writing exercise that I had 24 hours to complete--and from there, finding out whether I got the internship or not. I love what WRI stands for and the work that the team accomplishes together, but the communication is sorely lacking. Prepare to sit and wait unemployed while a "decision" is being made, and hope that the process won't take a full month and a week long like it did for me.
Interview Questions:
Why do you want to work at WRI?

When working on a project, what are the steps you would take to complete it?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions: I was contact by an automatic email and requested interview times. I had the initial interview which was about 20 min long, and then the second interview was with one additional person and that was about 30-45 min. I never heard back after the second interview about my status. I reached out directly to the hiring manager after some time had passed, and still did not receive a response.
Interview Questions: Scenario question about if the entire world ran on renewable energy, would public transportation still be an important initiative?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions: I submitted an application online and received an email several weeks later asking to set up and interview. We discussed the position and my previous research background and then I received an email later that day offering the position.
Interview Questions: What previous research experience do you have? Why did you apply for this position?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Apr 2020
Interview Descriptions: After submitting my cover letter and resume I had a phone interview with the supervisor and a manager from the department.  Roughly two weeks later they followed up to ask for 2-3 references and provided a mock assignment.
Interview Questions:
Why WRI? 

What experience do you have that will prepare you for this specific role?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was relatively easy, with only one interview. There was a team of three people that I met with virtually. I was offered the position after one interview and providing some references and writing samples.
Interview Questions: They asked me to describe in depth my research experience

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: My two interviewers were really interested in what specific experiences prepared me for this position, especially with regards to data analysis. Overall, it was a positive experience and I accepted my offer.
Interview Questions: What separates you from other applicants?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Ciudad de Mexico) in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions:
Entrevista varía según el puesto. 

Tres entrevistas con preguntas de conocimiento sobre el puesto. Primera entrevista de "Screening y conocimientos generales", segunda entrevista sobre escenarios supuestos y posibles soluciones con jefe directo y tercera entrevista con director del área.
Interview Questions: Escenario de un proyecto y cómo lo resolverías

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: Normal Interview, not hard. First they did an introduction of the company then asked me some questions related to my resume. Also, asked me BQ and related work experience.  Last they asked for three references.
Interview Questions: what will you do if you have a different opinion from your teammates?

title: Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
Overall basically felt like the hiring committee was winging it. I was originally told the process would include an initial phone screen, a more in-depth phone interview, a writing test, then an in-person panel interview. Completed all those, was then put through two additional phone interviews and asked for a references check.
Was then told the final decision was tougher than expected, so much so that they were considering adding an additional role to hire us both. Received a very generic rejection email and, in response to my question about the other role, was told it was no longer an option.
Interview Questions: Why WRI vs similar nonprofits/think tanks?

title: Program Coordinator Interview

Interview Descriptions:
I interviewed for a job with them last year. My friend had a similar experience with them very recently, so I decided to pop in here and leave a review. 

It was just a phone interview for me, brief (as was scheduled), but the hiring person I spoke with was honestly quite rude and sounded distracted/annoyed the whole interview. I think we both realized I was not a good fit for this role. For sure. But combined with having heard negative things from 2 colleagues who had worked there (Washington DC) previously a few years ago, it all left a sour taste in my mouth regarding this company. It was the first time I had ever sort of given up halfway through an interview and just wanted it to end, personally. Just being honest.
Interview Questions: Describe your experiences working backwards on your resume.

title: Finance Analyst Interview

title: Intern Interview

title: Mid-management Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
The communication with the team (email) was good. The phone interview was quite unprofessional: the person was over 10 mn late and didn't apologize, had a very poor connection, in addition to dogs barking in the background (working from home?), and abruptly ended up the interview after 20 mn because they had another meeting. 
If you're not interested in interviewing candidates, then don't do it! Candidates are not responsible for your poor time management and interview skills.  WRI should provide recruitment training to their managers, some really don't give a positive image of the organization.
I have interviewed many candidates in previous jobs, and always ensured to at a minimum be respectful and listen to what they had to say if I invited them.
Interview Questions: How would you accomplish the main tasks requested?

title: Research Role, Mid to Senior Level Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
Terrible process.  Had two interviews with my prospective supervisor - one on the phone and one in person with a panel.  Both times the interviewer was 15 minutes late, which is not by itself terrible, but considering I work full-time and they offered no apology, I considered quite rude.  Both times the interviewer spoke about 80% of the time and repeatedly interrupted me.  I found the questions to be combative and quite frankly inappropriate for the level of the position and my level of experience.  At the end of the interview, I told the person that I had not had an interview like this one for about 12-13 years (for an entry-level consulting position), that I was shocked by the combative nature of the questions, and that I was hoping that it would be a more collaborative tone. An hour after the interview, I wrote and informed them that I was no longer interested in the position.  Later on I looked up the interviewer's teaching profile (they were formerly an academic) and found mostly negative reviews and low ratings at two universities.  

WRI does good work, but they need to seriously reconsider their hiring process.  Positions that require a PhD and 10+ years of experience do not need to take a writing exam (would have been the next step) and interviewers should be trained in appropriate techniques and questions.
Interview Questions: What would an appropriate sample size be?

title: Senior Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at World Resources Institute
Interview Descriptions:
This is actually for two interviews for different positions. In the first, I was asked an illegal question about my ancestry. In the second, I was asked a similar one, both times very casually, as one might do when meeting someone in social circumstances. The first process went on for months with various phone and Skype calls, and then an in-person with several people over an entire day. The second position involved only one call, and then an entire day in their office, including a presentation. Both times, the in-office process seemed chaotic with them running around to find conference rooms, etc., and I wasn't provided a schedule in either case. 

If you look around their office and website, you will see a very homogeneous American work force with a sprinkling of foreigners, but either no or very few US minorities. Very strange for an institution based in DC that presumes to handle global problems, but with a staff with very limited perspectives.
Interview Questions: Illegal questions re ancestry

The human resources department spoke with me again (via phone) after the second interview was conducted to follow up.

title: GIS Analyst Interview

The first 2 rounds were the longer interview rounds wit the first being a phone screening followed by a panel. I was then asked to make a 30 min presentation related to geospatial analysis which was followed by another half our of interviewing with the extended GFW team. Lastly, I wrote the written test that had 3 GIS related questions.

The whole process took so long which needs to be rectified. Yes, every team is busy but I thought that is what sets WRI and GFW team apart.

title: Communications Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions:
A phone interview followed by two in-person interviews and a writing assignment (on site). The phone interview was with just an HR person, the first in-person interview with a group of 5 (one of them was video-conferenced in) from various departments of the Institute, including HR and Communications.
The interviews were very standard but pleasant. 
The third interview included a 30-minute talk with an HR rep about salary and benefits. At the end of the third interview, I was given a scientific text and asked to write a press release about it. The assignment itself was easy but it had a "high school exam" feel to it, which I found inappropriate for a professional organization in Washington DC. 
However, the most inappropriate aspect of the interview/hiring process was that after the third interview, I was told I was one of two candidates left in the running, and asked to submit references - which they never checked.
Interview Questions: The interviews were really standard, including questions about your greatest strengths and weaknesses. One question I found interesting was that I was asked how much push-back (in form of promotions, salary raises, etc) they should expect from my current employer if I were to leave for WRI.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in May 2011
Interview Descriptions:
Asked some behavior questions and let me express my thinking of their current project.
Asked me what date I can start to work. But they need someone to start pretty quick and I can't finish my current project. That's the reason I didn't get in.
The interview was easy. And the people were friendly. Must be nice to work with if there was no time conflict.
Interview Questions: Are you better in working independently or as a team?

title: International Climate Policy Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in May 2009
Interview Descriptions: I only had a phone interview.  It was a cold call; I thought I was returning a call to set up an actual meeting, but ended up having an in-depth interview over the phone.  Questions were pretty standard - asked me about my background, different experiences listed on my resume and why I wanted this position.  Also, how my particular skills would be an asset for the job.
Interview Questions: no specific question - it was more that I was unprepared because there was no indication that there would be an interview when I was returning a voicemail.

title: Environmental Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at World Resources Institute (Washington, DC) in Jan 2009
Interview Descriptions: Did initial phone screening interview with lower level employee.  Did another phone interview with two higher level employees.  After a week was asked to come in for a full day interview with 6 people.  Was flown in and put up in hotel during process which took about 3/4 of the day to complete.  One week later received offer letter, contract and phone call about position with 2 weeks to respond yes or no.
Interview Questions: Walk us through your resume
